ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Reasonably comprehensive look at exposure assessment, that uses both written and interactive exercises to help qualify and critique methodology and robustness of data collection per environmental stressors. Slightly skewed toward airborne stressors. But the examples are robust and engaging. Especially edifying: the week-long personal monitoring challenge and the critiques of landmark, (and not so landmark) research papers. The guest lecturers generally did a great job providing not only a change of pace and preview into other fields/disciplines/exposures.
It is a small class, which is great. Also a lot of topics covered. Though

The main strength of the course is that it is structured very efficiently. At the beginning of the semester we focus on building a foundation of the general concepts of exposure assessment. The second half of the semester allows us to put that knowledge to use in a variety of environmental health topics. Guest lectures really added to that portion of the class as well as the class discussions that we had with the guests. I would have enjoyed doing more exposure assessment assignments (e.g. air particulate, audio) without taking away from other assignments. The term paper assignment was a great way to end the course and really bring all of the topics together into a cohesive project.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Brian Leaderer  Knowledgeable and responsible
Instructor: Brian Leaderer  He is very responsible and patient.

Instructor: Brian Leaderer  Knowledgeable, prompting, patient, engaging. Anecdotes aid in understanding the complexity of exposure assessment and context of environmental stressors. Easily commands the quality of the material although the quantity makes it a bit difficult to capture/convey in only 2 hours. Always inviting participation and engagement.P.S. If Jodi Sullivan counts as a TA, she is wonderfully supportive.
Instructor: Brian Leaderer  Very enthusiastic and knowledgable lecturer. Responsive to student feedback.

Instructor: Brian Leaderer  Dr. Leaderer was engaging in lecture but his teaching can improve if he would solicit more class interaction. This is particularly the case for the first few lectures were the material was more dense. The best classes were the ones in which we had a discussion and I felt that I took away the most from them.
Instructor: Brian Leaderer  intrersting, informative, consider fot student

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Reasonably comprehensive look at exposure assessment, that uses both written and interactive exercises to help qualify and critique methodology and robustness of data collection per environmental stressors.
Good if you're interested in the subject.

I would highly recommend this course to another student. The course focuses on the general topics of exposure assessment while requiring us to critically analyzing important papers in the exposure assessment literature.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student. Because it is helpful to the future work.
